item.title: Analyzing Politics Review
item.description: Favorite and Least Favorite Content Favorite Chapters: Chapter Topic Reason 4 Condrocet’s Paradox and Arrow’s Theorem Very unintuitive results about voting and group preferences 6 Strategic Behavior Show how rules can affect legislative outcomes Least Favorite Chapters: Chapter Topic Reason 8, 9 Cooperation Models too simplistic, mostly implied that nobody would engage in collective action General Impressions Recently I’ve been reading a book called “Analyzing Politics” by Kenneth A Shepsle, which is an introduction to rational models in political science.

item.title: About
item.description: About Me Hi Everyone! I’m Jason Yang, a 4th year Economics Major and Math Minor at the University of Chicago. I’ve produced some (probably mediocre) research in Financial Economics as an Undergrad and currently love reading interesting articles published on the American Economic Review, Journal of Political Economy, and Journal of Finance. Coffee is my big hobby; I currently roast and brew single origin coffees from around the world. About the Blog I have the blog divided by Category and Tag

item.title: Local Ethiopia Yirgacheffe
item.description: I was surprised to find a bag of beans from Ethiopia Yirgacheffe roasted yesterday at a local roastery (Kusanya Cafe) at Whole Foods. The beans had a very smooth mouthfeel and were very bright and fruity. I tried V60 first with the tabbed & bleached paper filters. The coffee felt quite thin but definitely not lacking in personality. The Clever Dripper with a cloth filter tasted similar but had a much fuller body (which I personally prefer) because of the additional dissolved oils.

item.title: Nesco Roasting Guide and Review
item.description: I got a great deal on a Nesco roaster ($45 for an open-box product, normally $80) and figured it would be great value at that price. I’ve used this roaster ~50 times, which should be enough to comment a bit on a very simple machine. I’ll update this post as I collect more data and learn new things about the roaster. Pricing If you want to buy a Nesco, you probably won’t have to buy it at full price ($80).
